questions.question: What is the main advantage of using smart contracts?

questions.question: What happens during an overflow attack on a smart contract?

answers.a: A value drops below the minimum representable limit
answers.b: A function calls an untrusted contract recursively
answers.c: A value exceeds the maximum representable limit and wraps around
answers.d: Private data is accessed by external users

explanations.b: Incorrect. This refers to a re-entrancy attack, not an overflow.
explanations.c: Correct. An overflow occurs when a value exceeds the maximum limit (e.g., 255 for Uint8) and wraps around due to the finite range of the data type.
explanations.d: Incorrect. This relates to accessing private data, not an overflow.

questions.question: What is a re-entrancy attack in the context of smart contracts?

answers.a: An attack where private variables are read by external users
answers.b: An attack where a function recursively calls an untrusted contract to drain funds
answers.c: An attack where integer values exceed their maximum limit
answers.d: An attack where a contract fails due to insufficient gas

explanations.a: Incorrect. This relates to accessing private data, not re-entrancy.
explanations.b: Correct. A re-entrancy attack occurs when a function makes an external call to an untrusted contract, which then recursively calls back to drain funds.
explanations.c: Incorrect. This describes an overflow attack, not re-entrancy.
explanations.d: Incorrect. Gas issues are unrelated to re-entrancy attacks.

questions.question: Why is storing sensitive information like passwords in a smart contract a bad idea?

answers.a: Because smart contracts are slow to process sensitive data
answers.b: Because blockchains are transparent, allowing anyone to read private variables
answers.c: Because smart contracts cannot store data securely
answers.d: Because passwords increase the gas cost of transactions

explanations.a: Incorrect. Processing speed is not the primary issue here.
explanations.b: Correct. Blockchains are transparent, so even private variables can be read by anyone, making it insecure for sensitive data like passwords.
explanations.c: Incorrect. Smart contracts can store data securely, but transparency undermines privacy.
explanations.d: Incorrect. Gas costs are unrelated to the security of storing passwords.
